A SUGGESTION FOR THE FRESHMEN
"While, as a rule, the University authorities do not take cognizance of minor disorders that occur off of the campus, when such
disorders assume the form of kidnapping and forcible detention from
classes and laboratories, the Faculty has to take cognizance of same."
Thus reads a portion of a statement issued recently by the Dean of
the College of Arts and Sciences concerning the interclass struggles
occurring in connection with the annual banquet season.
THE NEWS-LETTER, were it inclined to take such a stand,
doubts whether its influence with the undergraduate body would
prove of sufficient strength to effect a complete abolishment of one
of Hopkins' oldest traditions. The sentiment on the campus seems
to be overwhelmingly in favor of the continuance of class rivalry in
conjunction with the lower class banquets.
The present Freshman Class must, next spring, set a precedent
for future years. The Faculty, it seems, will not interfere as long
as any accompanying "disorders" remain "minor" and as long as
no men are forcibly detained from classes. In the past, Faculty intreference has not proved pleasent to those men who were the objects
of the attention. There seems but one course for future under-classmen to pursue : they must remain within the stipulated bounds.
We would suggest, that if the Class of 1926 feels that their. banquet next spring will not prove a success without the presence of
desirable members of the Class of 1927, no attempt be made to capture these men until after four P. M. of the day on which the banquet
is to be held. In this way much of the preliminary unrest and disorder can be eliminated and the enjoyment of the festivities will
not be marred by drastic Faculty action.

INSPECTION
The Hopkins campus is transformed into a miniature battlefield
as the R. 0. T. C. unit utilizes every available moment in preparation for the annual War Departmen't inspection to be held on May
the fourteenth and fifteenth. Major Garey and his staff, the cadet
officers and the unit as a whole are bending every effort to effect the
restoration of the Johns Hopkins Unit to a coveted position on the
"Distinguished List."
For several years the Hopkins Unit ranked high on this list, its
military department was rated as one of the best in the country.
Last year, the War Department made a change in its system of marking and, when the list of colleges that had made the Dinstinguished
List was announced, Hopkins was conspicuously absent. Since then,
the original plan of marking has been restored, and indications seem
to point to the fact that the University will regain its place of honor.
The officers in charge of the unit, however, are determined to take
no chances on an unfavorable -decision. The two weeks before the
inspection are being spent in thorough reviewing of theoretical subjects, in drilling and in preparation for the annual manoeuvres.
To be on the Distinguished List is a great honor for any college:
Major Garey and his staff and the R. O.T. C:imitare-dbing-dll in their
power. The under graduate body should lend them its unqualified
support.

The First Electrochemist
ETROUS oxide, according to the science of a
century ago, was "the
principle of contagion when respired by animals in the minutest
quantities." Mere say-so.
Imaginative yet skeptical Humphrey Davy, who believed in experiment rather than in opinion,
"respired"lit and lived.
It was this restless desire to test
beliefs that made him one of the
founders of modern science. Electricity was a new force a century
ago. Davy used it,to decompose
potash, soda, and lime into potassium, sodium,_ and calcium, thus
laying the foundations of electrochemistry.,With a battery of two
thousand plates he produced the
first electric arc -harbinger of
modern electric illumination and
of the electric furnace.
Czar-Alexander I and Napoleon
met on-a raft to sign the Treaty of
Tilsit while Davy- was. revealing

General
9enerat office

the effects of electricity on matter.
"What is Europe?" said Alexander."We are Europe."
The treaty was at that time an
important political event, framed
by two selfish monarchs for the sole
purpose of furthering their personal_interests. Contrast with it
the unselfish_ efforts of Sir Humphrey Davy. His brilliant work
has resulted in scores of'practical
applications of electrolysis,:in,industry and.a wealth of chemical
knowledge-that bezefit,not himself but the entire world..
In the Research Laboratories of
the General Electric Company,for
instance, much has been done to
improve the electric furnace(a development of Davy's arc) and new
compounds have been electrochemically produced, which make
it easier to cast high-conductivity
copper, to manufacture special
tool steels;iand to produce carbides
for better arc lamps.

A SUGGESTION FOR THE FRESHMEN
"While, as a rule, the University authorities do not take cognizance of minor disorders that occur off of the campus, when such
disorders assume the form of kidnapping and forcible detention from
classes and laboratories, the Faculty has to take cognizance of same."
Thus reads a portion of a statement issued recently by the Dean of
the College of Arts and Sciences concerning the interclass struggles
occurring in connection with the annual banquet season.
THE NEWS-LETTER, were it inclined to take such a stand,
doubts whether its influence with the undergraduate body would
prove of sufficient strength to effect a complete abolishment of one
of Hopkins' oldest traditions. The sentiment on the campus seems
to be overwhelmingly in favor of the continuance of class rivalry in
conjunction with the lower class banquets.
The present Freshman Class must, next spring, set a precedent
for future years. The Faculty, it seems, will not interfere as long
as any accompanying "disorders" remain "minor" and as long as
no men are forcibly detained from classes. In the past, Faculty intreference has not proved pleasent to those men who were the objects
of the attention. There seems but one course for future under-classmen to pursue : they must remain within the stipulated bounds.
We would suggest, that if the Class of 1926 feels that their. banquet next spring will not prove a success without the presence of
desirable members of the Class of 1927, no attempt be made to capture these men until after four P. M. of the day on which the banquet
is to be held. In this way much of the preliminary unrest and disorder can be eliminated and the enjoyment of the festivities will
not be marred by drastic Faculty action.

INSPECTION
The Hopkins campus is transformed into a miniature battlefield
as the R. 0. T. C. unit utilizes every available moment in preparation for the annual War Departmen't inspection to be held on May
the fourteenth and fifteenth. Major Garey and his staff, the cadet
officers and the unit as a whole are bending every effort to effect the
restoration of the Johns Hopkins Unit to a coveted position on the
"Distinguished List."
For several years the Hopkins Unit ranked high on this list, its
military department was rated as one of the best in the country.
Last year, the War Department made a change in its system of marking and, when the list of colleges that had made the Dinstinguished
List was announced, Hopkins was conspicuously absent. Since then,
the original plan of marking has been restored, and indications seem
to point to the fact that the University will regain its place of honor.
The officers in charge of the unit, however, are determined to take
no chances on an unfavorable -decision. The two weeks before the
inspection are being spent in thorough reviewing of theoretical subjects, in drilling and in preparation for the annual manoeuvres.
To be on the Distinguished List is a great honor for any college:
Major Garey and his staff and the R. O.T. C:imitare-dbing-dll in their
power. The under graduate body should lend them its unqualified
support.

The First Electrochemist
ETROUS oxide, according to the science of a
century ago, was "the
principle of contagion when respired by animals in the minutest
quantities." Mere say-so.
Imaginative yet skeptical Humphrey Davy, who believed in experiment rather than in opinion,
"respired"lit and lived.
It was this restless desire to test
beliefs that made him one of the
founders of modern science. Electricity was a new force a century
ago. Davy used it,to decompose
potash, soda, and lime into potassium, sodium,_ and calcium, thus
laying the foundations of electrochemistry.,With a battery of two
thousand plates he produced the
first electric arc -harbinger of
modern electric illumination and
of the electric furnace.
Czar-Alexander I and Napoleon
met on-a raft to sign the Treaty of
Tilsit while Davy- was. revealing

General
9enerat office

the effects of electricity on matter.
"What is Europe?" said Alexander."We are Europe."
The treaty was at that time an
important political event, framed
by two selfish monarchs for the sole
purpose of furthering their personal_interests. Contrast with it
the unselfish_ efforts of Sir Humphrey Davy. His brilliant work
has resulted in scores of'practical
applications of electrolysis,:in,industry and.a wealth of chemical
knowledge-that bezefit,not himself but the entire world..
In the Research Laboratories of
the General Electric Company,for
instance, much has been done to
improve the electric furnace(a development of Davy's arc) and new
compounds have been electrochemically produced, which make
it easier to cast high-conductivity
copper, to manufacture special
tool steels;iand to produce carbides
for better arc lamps.
